text.tspan: Books and Magazines
Books to Prisoners
sends books to inmates
across the country. To request a book, write a
letterto Books to Prisoners c/o Left Bank Books, 92
Pike Street, Box A, Seattle, WA 98101. Include your
name, ID#, address, and requests. The organization
can send books every nine months.
Human Kindness Foundation
sends free inter
faith spiritual books and newsletters to anyone who
requests them from a prison or jail. Write to: HKF, PO
Box 61619, Durham NC 27715.
Prison Literature Project
sends books to inmates
once per year. To request a book, write a letter to Pris
oners Literature Project c/o Bound Together Books,
1369 Haight St., San Francisco, CA 94117. Include
your name, prison ID, address, and requests for books.
The organization limits book requests to once per
year, and does not supply law books and legal guides,
romances, horror, or Bibles and Christian literature.
Ms. Magazine
is a feminist magazine covering
current events, politics, and culture. Women in
prison can recieve a free membership by wrtiting
to Attn: Ms. In Prison Program, 1600 Wilson Blvd.
#801 Arlington, VA 22209
Positively Aware
sends is a free Bi-monthly
magazine subscription for individuals living with HIV.
They also publish an annual drug guide for HIV and
hepatitis C. For a subscription or a drug guide, write
to Positively Aware 5537 N. Broadway St., Chicago, IL
Earth First! Journal
sends is a quarterly journal
focused on the radical environmental movement.
Free subscriptions are available to inmates
nationwide. Write to PO Box 1112, Grants Pass, OR
Asheville Prison Book Project
sends books to
inmates in North Carolina. To request a book, write
to Asheville Prison Books Program c/o Downtown
Books and News, 67 N. Lexington Ave., Asheville,
NC 28801. Include name, ID#, and address.
Health, Mental Health, & Substance Abuse
AIDS Alabama
Provides supportive housing options
for people living with HIV, PrEP prescriptions, health
insurance assistance, substance abuse programming,
and mental health services. 3529 7th Ave S, Birming
RAINN - Rape, Abuse, And Incest National
Network
A national anti-sexual assault organi
zation that works in collaboration with rape crisis
centers across the country. Their services are free
and confidential and provided to survivors of all
identities. Call their line and be conencted to the
nearest sexual assault service provider. 800-656-
HOPE (4673)
The Alliance of AIDS Services – Carolina
Offer free HIV testing, free counseling sessions, a food
pantry, and support groups for people living with HIV.
• Tillery Place Office Park, 1637 Old Louisburg Road,
Raleigh NC 27604 • 919-834-2437 • www.aas-c.org
National Suicide Prevention Lifeline
provides
24/7 confidential support for people in crisis.The ho
tline also provides resources to individuals and family
members experiencing mental illness. The lifeline can
also recommend local crisis centers for access to local
resources. Call 1-800-273-8255
National Alliance on Mental Illness
NAMI
is a nationwide organization that oversees affiliate
locations across North Carolina and Alabama.
These locations conduct peer support groups and
educational programs that address the needs of
people living with mental illness.
North Carolina: NAMI North Carolina Office
309 W. Millbrook Road, Suite 121, Raleigh, NC
27609 • Mental Help Hotline: (800) 451-9682 •
General Contact: (919) 788-0801
Alabama: NAMI Alabama Office 1401 I-85 Park
way, Suite A Montgomery, AL 36106 •
Information, Resources, and Support: 800-950-
North Carolina Association of Free and
Charitable Clinics:
A network of affordable
healthcare providers for the uninsured or underin
sured. 1399 Ashleybrook Ln Suite 110,
Winston-Salem, NC 27103 • 336-251-1111
Legal Resources
Prison Organizing Continued
National Coalition to Protect Civil Freedoms
A coalition of national and local organizations dedi
cated to educating the public about civil and political
injustices in the U.S. criminal justice system. P.O. Box
PEN Prison Writing Program
distributes a
Handbook for Writers in Prison, They also run an
annual Writing Contest. To enter the contest (before
September 1st each year) and request a handbook,
send a note to PEN Prison Writing Program 588
Broadway, Suite 303 New York, NY 10012
Partisan Defense Committee
Works to stand
up to racist, capitalist oppression and bring attention
to the class-war prisoner in the United States. New
York/Main Office: P.O. Box 99, Canal Street Station,
sandefense@earthlink.net.
CURE
A national organization committed to criminal
justice reform. Alabama Chapter: PO Box 190504
Birmingham, AL 35219 • National Headquarters: PO
Box 2310 Washington DC, 20013-2310
ACLU of Alabama and ACLU North Carolina
Take on a limited number of individual cases for civil
liberty violations that occurred in Alabama or North
Carolina. To request legal assistance, file a complaint
via mail.
For those convicted in Alabama: American Civil Lib
erties Union of Alabama P.O. Box 6179 Montgomery,
For those convicted in North Carolina: ACLU of
North Carolina PO Box 28004 Raleigh, NC 27611
NC Center On Actual Innocence
Provides
legal assistance for inmates convicted of a felony in
North Carolina with a credible claim of innocence. To
begin a claim, contact P.O. Box 52446 Shannon Plaza
Station, Durham, North Carolina 27717-2446
NC Prisoner Legal Services
Evaluate claims of
validity of sentences andconvictions as well as claims
of violations of civil rights within prisons. NCPLS
does not litigate cases; however, they may provide
legal advice and self-help packets on post-conviction
issues. North Carolina Prisoner Legal Services, Inc.
Equal Justice Initiative
litigates on behalf of
condemned prisoners, juvenile offenders, peo
ple wrongfully convicted, people denied effective
representation, and others whose trials were marked
by racial bias or prosecutorial misconduct. EJI takes
only a limited number of cases. Send claims to Equal
Justice Initiative 122 Commerce Street Montgomery,
Alabama 36104 • General Inquiries:
National Lawyers Guild
A national organization
of progressive and radical lawyers active in criminal
justice reform. Publishes a free “Jailhouse Lawyer
Handbook” available to all incarceated folks. The
Handbook contains limited information on the
American legal system and information on how to
file a federal lawstuit addressing poor conditions in
prisons. To request a handbook, write to: National
Lawyers Guild—Prison Law Project 132 Nassau Street,
Rm 922, New York, NY 10038
Southern Center for Human Rights
Provides
people facing the death penalty legal representation,
challenges human rights violations in prisons and jails,
advocates for criminal justice reform, and provides
legal information for inmates in Alabama. 60 Walton
4StruggleMag
Free magazine from the hearts and
minds of North American politcal prisoners. Free
prisoner subscriptions. It costs $1.20 to send a letter
to Canada.P.O. Box 97048 RPO Roncesvalles Ave.
Toronto, Ontario,M6R 3B3 Canada
Prisoner Legal News
Monthly publication that
provides cutting edge review and anaysis of prisoner
rights, court rulings, and news concerning prison-re
lated issues. Prices information that enables prisoners
to seek the frotection and enforcement of prisoners’
rights at the grassroot level. $3.50 sample issue/$30
one year subscription. Request a catalog of legal
books. To subscribe, send a check or money order for
the correct amount to: Prison Legal News, P.O. Box
1151, Lake Worth, FL 33460.
Lewisburg Prison Project
Produces and sells low-
cost ($1-$3)legal bulletins related to litigation, First
Amendment Rights, Rights of Pretrial Detainees, Due
Process, Punishment, Medical Care, and Post-
Conviction information. Request a catalog by writing
to P.O. Box 128, Lewisburg, PA 17837-0128
Salvation Army
politically conservative, Chris
tian organization that provides parole assistance,
prerelease, job training, employment opportunities,
housing, and material aid.
North Carolina Headquarters: 501 Archale Drive
Alabama/Mississippi Headquarters: 1450 Riverside
Drive, Jackson, MS 39202 • 601-969-7560
